Can you please at least try running one event through the BMC?
Just use ```diff``` tool. It's the same code.

Diff isn't a test and this code doesn't have any unit test coverage that I'm aware of.  Diff also reports changes.  If you're not able or willing to test this, please just let me know and I'll get the testing done.  It's not meant to be onerous or blocking and my expectation was that setting up and running the test would've taken a trivial amount of time if you had already set them up.

Which changes are you seeing with 'diff' tool?

If the C++ code is the same then there cannot be any change in the behavior, right?
So it would not need any testing.

The function names are qualified now, so 'diff' might report that. But it's not a behavior change.

I did not intend to do any behavior change.

> Which changes are you seeing with 'diff' tool?

Gerrit is showing 100+ new lines:
+414 -280

That's not to say these lines don't make sense, but "look at diff and you'll see they're the same" isn't the answer.

> 
> If the C++ code is the same then there cannot be any change in the behavior, right?
> So it would not need any testing.

That's your opinion.  Testing in the commit message is about more than just one commit or keeping you honest, it's about communicating "this is the way to test this change" and to make sure that others can replicate. 

> 
> The function names are qualified now, so 'diff' might report that. But it's not a behavior change.
> 
> I did not intend to do any behavior change.

I understand, doesn't change the need for a testing statement on the commit message.

> That's not to say these lines don't make sense, but "look at diff and you'll see they're the same" isn't the answer.

It's called code review and it is time consuming. If you don't trust me that i just copy-pasted the functions from one file to the other, you can do it yourself and between what i did and what you did there will be no diff, after running clang-format.

Then you don't have to actually look at the code or diff individual functions.

I get that it's not the same since the indentation has changed.
I'm not trying to avoid doing necessary work of testing behavior changes, but this is simply the indentation change that's causing a lot of the diff.
There is no testing work needed here since the code is exactly the same.

> That's your opinion. Testing in the commit message is about more than just one commit or keeping you honest, it's about communicating "this is the way to test this change" and to make sure that others can replicate. 

This change is analogous to your change in b729096d0a787abe2a7e8a9a2d1ea12b5e1540fb
where you refactored a large lambda into a function (nice change, happy about that one). I don't see why different rules apply to me. There you also put the commit message as 

> Tested: Inspection Only.

For further examples of 'Inspection Only' we have

7945eeed0fe8f9c7bf07669294499ae0108da1d3 (Ed, refactoring)
d3e9c3a24a804d159b473002dfc99eb86ac3cd91 (Ed)
ac1e1246464e28fe4313ba936a6b8f64ec65bb12 (Ed)
f2a8e57ede74a8252100b2281e3f4d170aa69391 (Gunnar)
...

> > That's not to say these lines don't make sense, but "look at diff and you'll see they're the same" isn't the answer.
> 
> It's called code review and it is time consuming. If you don't trust me that i just copy-pasted the functions from one file to the other, you can do it yourself and between what i did and what you did there will be no diff, after running clang-format.
> 
> Then you don't have to actually look at the code or diff individual functions.
> 
> I get that it's not the same since the indentation has changed.
> I'm not trying to avoid doing necessary work of testing behavior changes, but this is simply the indentation change that's causing a lot of the diff.

It's more than an indentation change.  We moved from header-only to header + cpp unit.  That on its own is fine and good, so telling me to look at the diff doesn't really help here, as the diff can't show that nothing has changed.

> There is no testing work needed here since the code is exactly the same.

Considering that at a minimum I rebased it yesterday manually, and I believe you did at least once, there's no guarantee the code is still the same.

> 
> > That's your opinion. Testing in the commit message is about more than just one commit or keeping you honest, it's about communicating "this is the way to test this change" and to make sure that others can replicate. 
> 
> This change is analogous to your change in b729096d0a787abe2a7e8a9a2d1ea12b5e1540fb
> where you refactored a large lambda into a function (nice change, happy about that one). I don't see why different rules apply to me. There you also put the commit message as 
> 
> > Tested: Inspection Only.

Ah, I see the confusion.  Because there's automated tests that have coverage of that code, so if it were broken, it would immediately show in CI.  To my knowledge, event service (the code changed here) does not have automated tests or unit tests like that commit does.

> 
> For further examples of 'Inspection Only' we have
> 
> 7945eeed0fe8f9c7bf07669294499ae0108da1d3 (Ed, refactoring)
> d3e9c3a24a804d159b473002dfc99eb86ac3cd91 (Ed)
> ac1e1246464e28fe4313ba936a6b8f64ec65bb12 (Ed)
> f2a8e57ede74a8252100b2281e3f4d170aa69391 (Gunnar)
> ...

You'll note that these each hit some combination of:
- Code covered by redfish-service-validator, which runs automatically.
- Either a net same or net negative code lines diff that's trivial to review.  (this code is +100 lines)
- A change made by script automation, so far less likely that it had any human errors in it.

In comparison to this patch, those make these things different.  You'll also note that the vast majority of my commits do have testing statements.

I'd also point out again that if testing eventservice is too onerous for you, I've offered to do it for you.  For the amount of time invested in this thread, we could've tested this patch several times by now.  If you'd like to change the policy on how we test things, doing it in this commit isn't the way to accomplish that.  If that's a discussion you'd like to have, I'm happy to have it outside of this patch.

>>     For further examples of 'Inspection Only' we have

>>    7945eeed0fe8f9c7bf07669294499ae0108da1d3 (Ed, refactoring)
    d3e9c3a24a804d159b473002dfc99eb86ac3cd91 (Ed)
    ac1e1246464e28fe4313ba936a6b8f64ec65bb12 (Ed)
    f2a8e57ede74a8252100b2281e3f4d170aa69391 (Gunnar)
    ...

> You'll note that these each hit some combination of:

>   Code covered by redfish-service-validator, which runs automatically.
    Either a net same or net negative code lines diff that's trivial to review. (this code is +100 lines)
    A change made by script automation, so far less likely that it had any human errors in it.

> In comparison to this patch, those make these things different. You'll also note that the vast majority of my commits do have testing statements.

Agree here.

> I'd also point out again that if testing eventservice is too onerous for you, I've offered to do it for you. 

Thanks. If you have the time to test it, that would be great.

Tested it similar to another commit recently made in that area, using 
redfish service validator and redfish event listener.
Great, thank you.
FYI, we'll likely have merge conflicts between this and https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/74878.  We'll get them figured out.

BTW, thank you very much for going above an beyond breaking these classes up.  I was only asking that the two methods you were modifying got broken out, but I really appreciate you doing more.  If any of the requested fixes or rebase changes are too onerous for you to make, please let me know and we'll get it figured out.
Acknowledged
Similar to `event-log.hpp`, can this be `redfish-core/include/event-service/event_log_objects_type.hpp`?
Done
For the consistency with the other cases, would it be better to use "_" in the filename like`redfish-core/include/event-service/event_log.hpp`?
+1 naming convention for files is underscores.
Acknowledged

Can we just remove the "event-service" folder for now?  It's not clear to me what it would represent, and certainly the rest of the files in this folder don't follow that pattern now.  For this patch, lets keep the folder structure flat, and if we want to make a deeper folder structure, lets do it in a different patch.
i can remove it if you prefer the flat layout.
Thank you
include <string_view>

I'm going with a different refactoring for the next revision.
So this may no longer apply. Feel free to review again.
#include <string_view>

I'm going with a different refactoring for the next revision.
So this may no longer apply. Feel free to review again.

#include <random> // std::uniform_int_distribution
#include <utility> // std::pair

I'm going with a different refactoring for the next revision.
So this may no longer apply. Feel free to review again.
I see a lot of these includes that don't look correct.  Could you please give this a first pass for headers that aren't used?
For a concrete example, flat_map is not used in this header.
Done
There was a conflict in the last rebase that I just fixed.

I'm wondering why `subscription.cpp` needs to be created?
Can this class body implementation be done as a part of `subscription.hpp`?

By doing this way, it may loose the benefit of inlining functions.
For example, previously `matchSseId()` was inlined when it is referenced from `event_service_manager.hpp`. Now, since it is moved to `subscription.cpp`, it seems not inlined anymore.
In fact, I think most of functions of `Subscription` class becomes non-inlined with this.

> I'm wondering why `subscription.cpp` needs to be created?
> Can this class body implementation be done as a part of `subscription.hpp`?
> 
> By doing this way, it may loose the benefit of inlining functions.
> For example, previously `matchSseId()` was inlined when it is referenced from `event_service_manager.hpp`. Now, since it is moved to `subscription.cpp`, it seems not inlined anymore.

How are you verifying the inlining?  Keep in mind, the inline keyword doesn't actually effect inlining anymore, it's just an indication that the same definition might show up twice.

> In fact, I think most of functions of `Subscription` class becomes non-inlined with this.

Is there a concrete reason that's a problem?

I think - having the inline functions (member functions as part of class) may allow the compiler to do the optimization if possible.
However, moving the body of the function into *.cpp (as a separate compilation unit) effectively disable such optimization even if they may be possible.

In my experiment, I see the image/usr/libexec/bmcwebd size differences 

    - 172370088 (with this)
    - 170208180 (moving funcs into inline)
My experimental code is https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/75858 to move most of member functions as inline.

I'm not able to reproduce those numbers, and those numbers are a bit suspect, because 172 MB wouldn't even fit into the 64MB bmc flash.  Maybe you were looking at an unoptimized and unstripped build?

FWIW, I'm seeing a < 200 byte difference with this patch when I run builds in yocto.
